dt: {bc}to tell or make known (something, such as something wrong or damaging to oneself) {bc}{sx|admit||}
{bc}to acknowledge (sin) to God or to a priest
{bc}to declare faith in or adherence to {bc}{sx|profess||}

dt.t: Breeze, bird, and flower {wi}confess{/wi} the hour …

dt: {bc}to unburden one's sins or the state of one's conscience to God or to a priest

pt: {sc}acknowledge{/sc} {sc}admit{/sc} {sc}own{/sc} {sc}avow{/sc} {sc}confess{/sc} mean to disclose against one's will or inclination. {sc}acknowledge{/sc} implies the disclosing of something that has been or might be concealed.
{sc}admit{/sc} implies reluctance to disclose, grant, or concede and refers usually to facts rather than their implications.
{sc}own{/sc} implies acknowledging something in close relation to oneself.

pt.t: must {it}own{/it} I know little about computers

pt: {sc}avow{/sc} implies boldly declaring, often in the face of hostility, what one might be expected to be silent about.
{sc}confess{/sc} may apply to an admission of a weakness, failure, omission, or guilt.

et: Middle English {it}confessen{/it} "to admit, confess, (of a priest) hear a confession," borrowed from Anglo-French {it}confesser{/it} (also continental Old French), derivative of {it}confés{/it} "confessed, shriven," going back to Latin {it}confessus,{/it} past participle of {it}confiteor, confitērī{/it} "to admit (a fact, the truth of a statement or charge), reveal," from {it}con-{/it} {et_link|con-|com-} + {it}fateor, fatērī{/it} "to accept as true, acknowledge, profess," probably a verbal derivative based on Indo-European {it}*b{sup}h{/sup}h{inf}2{/inf}-to-{/it} "spoken" or {it}*b{sup}h{/sup}h{inf}2{/inf}-t-{/it} "who speaks," from the verbal base {it}*b{sup}h{/sup}eh{inf}2{/inf}-{/it} "speak, say," whence also Latin {it}for, fārī{/it} "to speak, say" {ma}{mat|ban:1|}{/ma}
shortdef: to tell or make known (something, such as something wrong or damaging to oneself) : admit
to acknowledge (sin) to God or to a priest
to receive the confession of (a penitent)
